column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.RoleAnnotation|roles
#Text=Mr.
#Text=Vilovic' (Croatia): Let me begin by extending\r
#Text=our congratulations to you, Mr.
#Text=President, and your\r
#Text=delegation on your presidency of the Security Council\r
#Text=for the month of October, and by assuring you of the\r
#Text=full support of my delegation.
#Text=I also thank you and\r
#Text=your delegation for initiating this meeting and bringing\r
#Text=the Council together to discuss an issue that is\r
#Text=critically important to the Republic of Croatia and,\r
#Text=surely, to all nations.
#Text=Allow me to extend a warm welcome to\r
#Text=Ms.
#Text=Michelle Bachelet and wish her success in her\r
#Text=future work as the first Executive Director of the newly\r
#Text=established gender entity, UN Women, and Under-\r
#Text=Secretary-General for Gender Equality and the\r
#Text=Empowerment of Women.
#Text=Given her high political\r
#Text=stature and experience, we deem that Ms.
#Text=Bachelet will\r
#Text=enhance the gender equality agenda and that\r
#Text=UN Women will grow into the principal voice for\r
#Text=gender mainstreaming and the empowerment of\r
#Text=women.
#Text=Croatia aligns itself with the statement delivered\r
#Text=by the representative of Belgium on behalf of the\r
#Text=European Union.
#Text=Here, I would like to make additional\r
#Text=remarks in my national capacity.
#Text=The adoption by the Security Council of\r
#Text=resolution 1325 (2000) bears testimony to the progress\r
#Text=made during the past decade in the area of women and\r
#Text=peace and security.
#Text=This historic resolution has focused\r
#Text=much-needed attention on the question of women's\r
#Text=empowerment, which represents a priority for my\r
#Text=country.
#Text=While all the resolutions on women and peace\r
#Text=and security are equally important, resolution 1325\r
#Text=(2000) serves as an umbrella resolution in addressing\r
#Text=women's empowerment, their task as peacebuilders and\r
#Text=their fragile position as victims of war.
#Text=The Republic of Croatia welcomes the report of\r
#Text=the Secretary-General on the implementation of this\r
#Text=landmark resolution (S/2010/498), the recommendations\r
#Text=contained therein, as well as the presidential statement\r
#Text=adopted by the Council today(S/PRST/2010/22).
#Text=We\r
#Text=call upon the Security Council to endorse the indicators\r
#Text=developed by the Secretary-General as soon as\r
#Text=possible.
#Text=The commitments set forth by the resolution are\r
#Text=commendable, but translating words into action is the\r
#Text=only way of resolving the remaining issues - and the\r
#Text=issues are many.
#Text=As numerous situations on the agenda\r
#Text=of this Council have shown, women still have a long\r
#Text=way to go in order to fulfil their empowerment goals as\r
#Text=well as to fully realize their human rights, both in times\r
#Text=of war and peace.
#Text=The empowerment of women is\r
#Text=imperative to the full achievement of human rights, as\r
#Text=well as to overall economic and political development\r
#Text=and progress.
#Text=Although women are widely recognized\r
#Text=as effective agents of peace, they still have little access\r
#Text=to decision-making positions and peace negotiations.
#Text=More should be done.
#Text=Armed conflicts continue to have a devastating\r
#Text=impact on women and girls and are often accompanied\r
#Text=by gender-based violence, including the increasing\r
#Text=scale and brutality of sexual violence, often used as a\r
#Text=means of war.
#Text=Impunity for such acts of violence\r
#Text=against women is still prevalent and the prosecution\r
#Text=rate very low.
#Text=Even on Croatian territory, in the heart of Europe,\r
#Text=rape was used as a method of intimidation and terror\r
#Text=during the aggression to which Croatia was exposed in\r
#Text=the early 19905.
#Text=We are fully aware of the role both the\r
#Text=Security Council and the international community can\r
#Text=play in addressing sexual violence against women and\r
#Text=girls, especially when used by political or military\r
#Text=leaders as a means of achieving political or military\r
#Text=objectives.
#Text=We believe that the Security Council needs\r
#Text=to provide strong and effective leadership on this issue,\r
#Text=including by taking concrete action when necessary,\r
#Text=with the ultimate aim of eradicating this abhorrent\r
#Text=behaviour.
#Text=Such acts of violence demand further action\r
#Text=by the Security Council to strengthen the rule of law\r
#Text=and to end impunity.
#Text=They need to be thoroughly\r
#Text=investigated and perpetrators brought to account, and it\r
#Text=is therefore imperative for the International Criminal\r
#Text=Court, as well as national courts, to be the last instance\r
#Text=of justice for the victims and a reminder that there can\r
#Text=be no tolerance for the crime of rape.
#Text=We are pleased to see that progress has been\r
#Text=made in several areas and that the United Nations\r
#Text=system continues to engage in a wide range of good\r
#Text=practices.
#Text=We encourage the strengthening of the\r
#Text=coordination among United Nations agencies both at\r
#Text=Headquarters and in the field, especially in monitoring\r
#Text=and reporting on situations where parties to armed\r
#Text=conflict engage in rape and other sexual violence as a\r
#Text=means of war.
#Text=Nevertheless, more consistent and\r
#Text=comprehensive reporting on sexual violence would\r
#Text=enable the Council to address the protection of women\r
#Text=and children in a more systematic manner, whereas the\r
#Text=Council should include specific reporting requirements\r
#Text=in resolutions establishing or renewing mandates.
#Text=More needs to be done also at the national level.
#Text=The integration of the resolution has to be country-\r
#Text=driven, and Member States need to take responsibility\r
#Text=for its success by ensuring that it is integrated into\r
#Text=national policies.
#Text=We urge countries to apply a broad\r
#Text=gender-mainstreaming approach across Government,\r
#Text=for instance through a system-wide approach that links\r
#Text=development, humanitarian and defence issues.
#Text=All\r
#Text=plans should include civil society consultations, as well\r
#Text=as monitoring and reporting mechanisms.
#Text=I am pleased to say that Croatia has taken steps to\r
#Text=integrate the gender perspective into its national\r
#Text=security policy through its national strategy for the\r
#Text=promotion of gender equality, and is currently\r
#Text=developing its national action plan on the\r
#Text=implementation of resolution 1325 (2000), which is\r
#Text=expected to be adopted in 2011.
#Text=Under the leadership\r
#Text=of its first female Prime Minister, Croatia will continue\r
#Text=to give its firm support to all areas of the women and\r
#Text=peace and security agenda.
#Text=We see it as a gender-based\r
#Text=peace agenda that involves addressing the\r
#Text=disproportionate effect of conflict on women and\r
#Text=combating sexual violence.
#Text=It is also about securing the\r
#Text=full, equal and effective participation of women at all\r
#Text=stages of the peace process, giving them an equal role\r
#Text=in the prevention and resolution of conflicts, as well as\r
#Text=in peacebuilding.
#Text=The realization of these goals is\r
#Text=essential to safeguarding basic human rights and\r
#Text=achieving human security and lasting peace.
